choices.D:
PROMPT Enter table name &&x -
SELECT employee_id FROM &x WHERE last_name = ‘King’;
choices.C:
PROMPT Enter table name &x -
SELECT employee_id FROM &&x WHERE last_name = ‘King’;
choices.A:
PROMPT Enter table name &x -
SELECT employee_id FROM &x WHERE last_name = ‘King’;

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
PROMPT Enter table name &&x -

The && (double ampersand) ensures that the value for the variable x is stored in the session after it is entered.
The PROMPT statement is used to display a message for the user to input the value.
SELECT employee_id FROM &x WHERE last_name = 'King';

The &x (single ampersand) refers to the variable x that was already defined by the && mechanism in the previous step. It does not prompt again because the variable is already stored.

Selected Answer: C
C. PROMPT Enter table name &x -
SELECT employee_id FROM &&x WHERE last_name = ‘King’;

An & prefix to an undefined substitution variable, which is referenced twice in the same query, will prompt for a value twice.

Selected Answer: D
C prompted twice, while D prompted only once.

Selected Answer: D
D, && performs an implicit DEFINE while & doesn't
I thought & always prompts, even if there was && before it, but this question just made me realize this, as all other answers are wrong, including C.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
Test results:
A and C: prompted twice
B: did not prompt
D: prompted once the first time and then no prompt on rerun
Best answer: D

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
Correct C

Selected Answer: C
C is the right answer tested

Selected Answer: D
D is correct.
B will never show a prompt window.

comments.content: if you re run D it we will always prompt you to enter a value with C only once will prompt you

discussion.content: Tested D.

questions.question_text: Which set of commands will prompt only once for the name of the table to use in the query?

discussion.content:
create table customers 
(cust_last_name varchar2(10))

select * from customers;

insert into customers
values ('Anderson')
 
insert into customers
values('Ausson')

select replace (replace(cust_last_name,'son',''),'An','O') from customers; -- +
select replace (trim(trailing 'son' from cust_last_name),'An','O') from customers; -- trim should have only one character
select replace (substr (cust_last_name,-3),'An','O') from customers; -- both values are 'son'
select initcap(replace(trim('son' from cust_last_name),'An','O')) from customers; -- trim should have only one character

Selected Answer: A
A is the answer
A is the answer

choices.D: SELECT INITCAP(REPLACE(TRIM(‘son’ FROM cust_last_name), ‘An’, ‘O’)) FROM customers;
choices.B: SELECT REPLACE(TRIM(TRAILING ‘son’ FROM cust_last_name), ‘An’, ‘O’) FROM customers;

questions.question_text:
The CUSTOMERS table has a CUST_LAST_NAME column of data type VARCHAR2.

The table has two rows whose CUST_LAST_NAME values are Anderson and Ausson.

Which query produces output for CUST_LAST_NAME containing Oder for the first row and Aus for the second?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: EF
EF should be the correct answer
E;F tested

Selected Answer: EF
Tested column aliases cannot before the concatination unless you want to also inclunde them which means you need to add another ||

Selected Answer: EF
EF are correct.
A is incorrect as there are single & double commas instead of single commas only. Others are obviously wrong.
E, F are right.

choices.C: SELECT prod_id q’s not available” FROM product_status WHERE status = ‘OUT OF STOCK’;
choices.D: SELECT prod_id “CURRENT AVAILABILITY” || q’(‘s not available)’ FROM product_status WHERE status = ‘OUT OF STOCK’;
choices.A: SELECT prod_id || q”’s not available” FROM product_status WHERE status = ‘OUT OF STOCK’;
choices.E: SELECT prod_id || q’(‘s not available)’ FROM product_status WHERE status = ‘OUT OF STOCK’;
choices.F: SELECT prod_id || q’(‘s not available)’ “CURRENT AVAILABILITY” FROM product status WHERE status = ‘OUT OF STOCK’;
choices.B: SELECT prod_id || q’(‘s not available)’ ‘CURRENT AVAILABILITY’ FROM product_status WHERE status = ‘OUT OF STOCK’;

discussion.content:
A. DML statements always start new transactions. (X). Not always
 B. DDL statements automatically commit only data dictionary updates caused by executing the DDL. (X) Not "only" data dictionary
 C. A session can see uncommitted updates made by the same user in a different session. (X) in the same session
 D. A DDL statement issued by a session with an uncommitted transaction automatically commits that transaction.
 E. An uncommitted transaction is automatically committed when the user exits SQL*Plus.

Selected Answer: DE
D. A DDL statement issued by a session with an uncommitted transaction automatically commits that transaction
E. An uncommitted transaction is automatically committed when the user exits SQL*Plus

Selected Answer: AD
hix chatGPT said that

Selected Answer: AD
A : transaction contains of one or more dml statements or DDL statement
D : because DDL make commit before and after DDL statement
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/server.112/e40540/transact.htm#CNCPT016

Selected Answer: DE
The answer is DE

Selected Answer: BD
bd is correct
The answer is BE

Selected Answer: DE
should be DE
 SET AUTOCOMMIT does not alter the commit behavior when SQL*Plus exits. Any uncommitted data is committed by default.
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E11882_01/server.112/e16604/ch_twelve040.htm#BABEGEGC
True hehe

choices.C: A session can see uncommitted updates made by the same user in a different session.
choices.E: An uncommitted transaction is automatically committed when the user exits SQL*Plus.
choices.B: DDL statements automatically commit only data dictionary updates caused by executing the DDL.
choices.A: DML statements always start new transactions.
choices.D: A DDL statement issued by a session with an uncommitted transaction automatically commits that transaction.

questions.question_text: Which two are true about transactions in the Oracle Database? (Choose two.)
